questions.question:
Question 1: Human cardiac muscle contains  
.
questions.explanation:
Human heart contains both alpha and beta isoforms of the myosin heavy chain.  isoform has a 
lower myosin ATPase activity than the  isoform. •  isoform predominates in the adult atria. •  isoform predominates in the adult ventricles. • The spatial distribution contributes to the well coordinated contraction of the heart.

questions.question:
Question 2: Intercalated discs are seen in  
.
questions.explanation:
• Cardiac muscle fibres are made up of many individual cells connected in series and parallel with 
one another. • The areas where the end of one muscle fiber abuts on another, which always occur at Z lines, are 
called intercalated discs. • It provides a strong union between fibers, maintaining cell-to-cell cohesion, so that the pull of 
one contractile cell can be transmitted along its axis to the next. • It contains Desmosomes to prevent pulling apart of the cells when strain • At each intercalated disc, the plasma membrane fuses with one another forming gap junction 
which provide low resistance bridges for the spread of excitation from one fiber to another 
permitting the cardiac muscle to function as a syncytium. 165

questions.question:
Question 3: Activation of the sympathetic system increases the myocardial contractility of a patient. 
Which of the following is responsible for this positive inotropic effect?
questions.explanation:
Phosphorylation of phospholamban is responsible for the positive inotropic effect on the 
myocardium observed after the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. Phospholamban is a protein that regulates Ca2+ATPase in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. When 
phosphorylated, phospholamban stimulates the Ca2+ ATPase, resulting in greater uptake and 
storage of Ca2+ by the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Increased Ca2+ uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum has two effects: It causes faster relaxation (i.e., briefer contraction). it increases the amount of stored Ca2+ for release on subsequent beats. This positive inotropic effect has three important features: increased peak tension, increased rate 
of tension development, and faster rate of relaxation. Faster relaxation means that the contraction (twitch) is shorter, allowing more time for refilling. This effect is mediated via activation of 1 receptors, which are coupled via a Gs protein to 
adenylyl cyclase. Activation of adenylyl cyclase leads to the production of cAMP, activation of protein kinases, and 
phosphorylation of proteins that produce the physiologic effect of increased contractility.

questions.question: Question 4: Which among the following is the function of phospholamban?

options.c: Regulates calcium entry into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.explanation:
• Phospholamban is a protein that regulates SR Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA) in the sarcoplasmic 
reticulum. In its dephosphorylated state, phospholamban inhibits the Ca2+ ATPase, resulting in 
diminished uptake and storage of Ca2+ by the sarcoplasmic reticulum, while in its phosphorylated 
state, there is disinhibition of the Ca2+ ATPase leading to increased uptake and storage of Ca2+ 
by the sarcoplasmic reticulum. • Increased Ca2+ uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum has two effects: • It causes faster relaxation (i.e., briefer contraction). • it increases the amount of stored Ca2+ for release on subsequent beats. • Phosphorylation of phospholamban is responsible for the positive inotropic effect effect on the 
myocardium observed after the stimulation of sympathetic nervous system. • This effect is mediated via activation of 1 receptors, which are coupled via a Gs protein to 
adenylyl cyclase. • This positive inotropic effect has three important features: increased peak tension, increased rate 
of tension development, and faster rate of relaxation. • Faster relaxation means that the contraction (twitch) is shorter, allowing more time for refilling.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a feature of cardiac muscle?
questions.explanation:
166 
Sold by @itachibot Cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized due to long refractory period. In cardiac myocytes, depolarization proceeds rapidly and an overshoot of the zero potential is 
present. This is followed by a plateau before the membrane potential reaches the RMP (-90mV). 
This plateau phase lasts for 200 msec or more. Repolarization is therefore not complete until 
contraction is 50% completed. Phases of cardiac action potential • 0 Depolarisation and overshoot • Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels • 1 Initial rapid repolarization • Due to closure of Na+ channels and opening up of K+ channels • 2 Plateau phase • Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels • 3 late rapid repolarization • 4 Baseline (RMP) • Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux 
through K+ channels. • During phases 0 to 2 and about half of phase 3 of cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot 
be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until 
phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

questions.question: Question 6: The following graph displays which physiological law of the heart?
questions.explanation:
The diagram displays the Length-Tension relationship for a cardiac muscle explaining the Starling 
law of the heart. 167 
Sold by @itachibot In the body, the initial length of the fibers is determined by the degree of diastolic filling of the 
heart, and the pressure developed in the ventricle is proportional to the volume of the ventricle at 
the end of the filling phase (Starling law of the heart). • The developed tension increases as the diastolic volume increases until it reaches a maximum, 
then tends to decrease. • The decrease is due to beginning disruption of the myocardial fibers and not due to a decrease in 
the number of cross-bridges between actin and myosin as seen in skeletal muscle.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is true regarding excitation-contraction coupling in smooth muscle?

options.b: Sustained contraction occurs with high calcium concentration
options.c: Phosphorylation of actin is required for contraction
options.d: Cellular calcium concentration is essential to cause contraction

questions.explanation:
Increased cytosolic Ca2+ is essential for contraction of smooth muscles. Events in Excitation Contraction Coupling in Smooth Muscles. 168 
Sold by @itachibot A unitary smooth muscle is unique in that it can contract when stretched even in the absence of 
any extrinsic innervation. Stretch is followed by a decrease in membrane potential and an increase 
in the tone of the muscle. Other options: Option a: Troponin is absent in smooth muscle. Option b: Sustained contraction of the smooth muscle occurs even when the calcium 
concentration falls. This is mainly because of the latch-bridge mechanism where the myosin 
cross-bridges remain attached to the actin. This mechanism allows for maintaining the 
contraction with less expenditure of energy and is particularly important in the vascular smooth 
muscle. Option c: Unlike skeletal muscle where troponin binding is essential for contraction, the smooth 
muscle contraction requires phosphorylation of myosin (not actin).

questions.question: Question 9: Calmodulin is mostly both structurally and functionally related to
questions.explanation:
Calmodulin is structurally and functionally related to troponin. In place of troponin, smooth 
muscle cells contain a large amount of the regulatory protein calmodulin. Calmodulin is similar to troponin; it is different in the manner in which it initiates contraction. 
Calmodulin initiates contraction by activating the myosin light chain kinase. Troponin, on the 
other hand, initiates contraction by causing a conformational change in the tropomyosin molecule 
which then uncovers the active sites on the actin filament.

questions.question:
Question 10: A sustained contraction with little expenditure of energy is made possible by a latching 
mechanism in  
.
questions.explanation:
• Smooth muscles can maintain prolonged full tonic contraction with little use of energy (as little 
as 1/300 the energy required for comparable sustained skeletal muscle contraction) and with little 169 
Sold by @itachibot continued excitatory signal due to this mechanism. • This is due to the fact that even after dephosphorylation of myosin, the cross-bridges continue to 
cling on for some time. • The excitation coupling mechanism occurring in smooth muscle is similar to the skeletal muscles 
but for a few features: • The process is slow and a low energy mechanism. • There is no fixed length tension relationship as it shows the property of plasticity (smooth 
muscles behaving like a viscous mass rather than a rigidly structured tissue). • This mechanism is specially useful in vascular smooth muscles.

questions.question:
Question 11: The most distinguishing feature between skeletal muscle and smooth muscle is 162 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But, 
troponin is absent and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following acts to increase the release of calcium ions from the endoplasmic 
reticulum of a smooth muscle?
questions.explanation:
In response to a stimulus, the efflux of calcium from intracellular stores occurs through an 
Inositol triphosphate receptor (IP3R)- Ca+2 channel. The source of Ca+2 in smooth muscle contraction can be different depending on the activating 
stimulus. • The influx from the extracellular site through voltage or ligand-gated Ca+2 channels in the 
plasma membrane • Efflux from intracellular stores (eg, sarcoplasmic reticulum) through the RyR and the inositol 
triosephosphate receptor (IP3R).

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements regarding smooth muscle is false?

options.a: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential
options.b: Dense Bodies are present instead of Z lines
options.c: It can exert a variable tension at any given length
options.d: Sympathetic stimulation produces excitatory membrane potentials

questions.explanation:
Sympathetic stimulation (norepinephrine) of a smooth muscle produces inhibitory potentials and 
relaxation. Parasympathetic stimulation (or acetylcholine) causes depolarization and contraction in the 
smooth muscle. Smooth muscle can be divided into: • Unitary smooth muscle - has low-resistance gap junctions between individual muscle cells and 
functions in a syncytial manner • Multiunit smooth muscle - made up of individual units with few or nil gap junctions. Blood vessels have both unitary and multiunit smooth muscle in their walls. 170 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential with continuous irregular 
contractions independent of its nerve supply. This state of partial contraction is called tonus or 
tone. Option B: Dense bodies are present instead of Z lines in smooth muscle. These are bound to actin 
filaments by  -actinin. Option C: Smooth muscle can exert variable tension at any given length. This property is called 
plasticity. When a unitary smooth muscle is stretched, it first exerts increased tension. However, if 
it is held at this length after stretching, the tension gradually decreases. This is referred to as 
plasticity.

Question 14: Given below is the demonstration of tetanization in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. 
Identify the tetanising frequency. 163 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: All neurotransmitter are derived from amino acids
options.b: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter in the CNS

questions.explanation:
Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know, • The speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec. • The y-axis represents millivolts, the x-axis represents time. • The scale on the x-axis is 10mm. • The area under the graph represents the muscle contraction. Contraction period (latent period to maximum force of contraction) includes 3 scales = 30 mm. As paper speed is 1000mm/sec, Contraction period = 30mm = (30/1000) = 30 msec. Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1000/30 = 33Hz. Tetanization The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The 
adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle 
contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways: • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ■ber 
summations. • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to 
tetanization. When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually 
fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, 
this is called tetanization. Tetanization occurs in two ways: • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli. • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated 
stimuli. 171
